content: Occidental Petroleum (OXY) saw its IBD SmartSelect Composite Rating rise to 96 Thursday, up from 89 the day before. X The revised score means the stock currently tops 96% of all other stocks in terms of key performance metrics and technical strength. The market's biggest winners often have a 95 or higher rating in the early stages of a new price run, so that's an important benchmark to look for when looking for the best stocks to buy and watch. Occidental Petroleum is now out of buy range after breaking out from a 78.19 entry in a cup without handle. See How IBD Helps You Make More Money In StocksOne weak spot is the company's 77 EPS Rating, which tracks quarterly and annual earnings-per-share growth. Look for that to improve to 80 or better to show it's in the top 20% of all stocks. Its Accumulation/Distribution Rating of B shows moderate buying by institutional investors over the last 13 weeks. Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseThe company reported a 513% rise in earnings for Q1. It has now posted accelerating EPS growth for six consecutive quarters. Revenue growth increased 28%, up from 27% in the prior quarter. That marks two quarters of rising growth. Occidental Petroleum earns the No. 2 rank among its peers in the Oil & Gas-International Exploration & Production industry group. ConocoPhillips (COP) is the top-ranked stock within the group.RELATED:Which Companies Are Now Outperforming 95% Of All Stocks?See Which Stocks Just Came On — And Off — IBD's Top Stock Lists

Occidental Petroleum (OXY) is easily among the best energy stocks in the oil and gas space, helped by strong fundamentals and a bullish chart.It's also a member of IBD's Dividend Leaders screen, thanks in part to a healthy annualized dividend yield of 4%. Its last quarterly dividend of 77 cents a share was paid April 16.The oil giant, with a market capitalization of just over $53 billion, has operations in the U.S., the Middle East and Latin America.When the company reported fourth-quarter results in February, adjusted profit of 41 cents a share matched expectations. Sales growth accelerated from the third quarter, up 27% to nearly $3.59 billion.In the company's Permian Resources segment, average daily production volumes improved to 159,000 barrels of oil equivalent from 139,000 in the third quarter. Results were helped by increased drilling activity and well productivity. For 2018, the company forecasts 40% annual production growth in Permian Resources.Along with its fourth quarter earnings report, Occidental issued guidance for 2018, including a capital budget of $3.9 billion along with estimated production growth of 8% to 12%.At the end of last year, about 58% of the company's proved reserves was oil, 25% gas and 17% natural gas liquids. Of the total proved reserves, 60% comes from the U.S. and 40% is international.Strong earnings reports from other top stocks in the oil and gas sector have been commonplace in recent days. But the reaction to earnings has been a mixed bag.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseOil and gas producer Noble Energy (NBL) on Tuesday delivered a big earnings beat along with another quarter of accelerating sales growth, but shares gapped down on the news. It's still holding above a 31.84 buy point.Q1 results from Houston-based Occidental Petroleum are due May 8 after the close. Quarterly profit is expected to surge 373% from the year-ago quarter to 71 cents a share, according to Zacks. Sales are seen rising 26% to $3.74 billion.Occidental is holding near highs as it trades just below a 78.19 buy point of a cup-shaped base. Resistance has appeared near the buy point in recent days, but that doesn't weaken its technical picture any. It's still a breakout candidate.Shares fell 0.9% in light volume Tuesday, but Occidental managed a decent close, ending in the upper half of its intraday range.RELATED:Noble Energy Beats Ahead Of Results From Anadarko, Concho, Viper EnergyWhich Stocks Just Came On — And Off — IBD's Stock Lists?Best Dividend Stocks To Buy And Watch

On Thursday, Occidental Petroleum (OXY) got a positive adjustment to its Relative Strength (RS) Rating, from 68 to 73. X As you try to find the best stocks to buy and watch, keep a close on eye on relative price strength.This unique rating identifies technical performance by showing how a stock's price action over the last 52 weeks compares to that of the other stocks in our database. Decades of market research reveals that the top-performing stocks often have an 80 or better RS Rating as they launch their largest runs. See if Occidental Petroleum can continue to rebound and hit that benchmark. Looking For The Best Stocks To Buy And Watch? Start HereOccidental Petroleum is building a cup without handle with a 78.19 entry. See if it can clear the breakout price in heavy trading. Earnings grew 415% last quarter, up from 0% in the prior report. Revenue also increased, from 14% to 27%. Look for the next report on or around May 4.Occidental Petroleum holds the No. 2 rank among its peers in the Oil & Gas-International Exploration & Production industry group. ConocoPhillips (COP) is the top-ranked stock within the group.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Amid the recent slide in oil prices — due to top OPEC and non-OPEC producers reportedly discussing options to potentially boost production — oil stocks within the IBD Dividend Leaders are showing mixed action.XAmong the upstream oil stocks, Chevron (CVX) is near a potential buy zone. The stock is trading just above its 50-day line after a recent breakout above a 128 cup-with-handle buy point sputtered. Shares are about 2% below that level.The company has a 3.6% annualized dividend yield.Shares edged 0.2% higher in midday trade Friday.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseOccidental Petroleum (OXY) is trading just off a new high, as its recent breakout gains traction. Shares surged over 5% on May 9, as the stock broke out above a 78.19 cup-shaped base entry, according to MarketSmith chart analysis.As a catalyst, Occidental reported strong earnings and sales results, while resuming its share-repurchase plans.The stock has a highest-possible 99 IBD Composite Rating. The rating is a blend of key fundamental and technical metrics to gauge a stock's overall strength. Meanwhile, the relative strength line is nearing a new high, showing strong market outperformance.The company has a 3.6% dividend yield.The stock advanced over 2% Friday.Helmerich & Payne (HP) is seeing significant weakness, as it falls further below its 50-day line. Shares continue to draw a cup-with-handle base with a 74.46 buy point. The stock came less than 1% from the entry on May 17, but never exceeded the entry.Investors shouldn't focus on getting the best price, but the right price at the right time, which is when the stock moves above the proper buy point in heavy volume.The Accumulation/Distribution Rating has faltered, weakening from an A- to a C- over the last three weeks. The rating measures institutional buying and selling over the last quarter.The stock has a 4.3% yield.Shares declined over 1% in Friday trade.RELATED:Energy Stocks And Industry News: Oil, Gas, Solar, CoalWhy The Next Oil Bonanza Could Be Deep Under WaterOil Prices Close Below $68 As OPEC, Russia Eye These Production HikesThese High-Yielding Energy Stocks Dominate The Dividend Leaders List

With the price of crude briefly topping $75 a barrel, Wall Street's attention has turned to oil stocks like Exxon (XOM), ConocoPhillips (COP), Occidental Petroleum (OXY) and Hess (HES). Large investors may also be primed to pump up drilling equipment maker Cactus (WHD) into a new buy zone. X As a top 2018 IPO stock, Cactus…

Energy stocks were among the day's top performers in the stock market today, even as the price of oil reversed lower. After advancing as much as 1.6% — and topping $75 a barrel — crude oil prices turned lower midday. Five stocks within the Oil & Gas International Exploration & Production industry are trading near potential buy points, including ConocoPhillips (COP).XOil prices climbed early Tuesday due to supply worries out of Libya and Canada, but then reversed lower after Saudi Arabia affirmed the country's willingness to boost production to maintain stability.The Oil & Gas-International Exploration & Production industry is ranked No. 56 out of 197 industry groups.ConocoPhillips is etching a flat base with a 71.81 buy point, according to MarketSmith chart analysis. Shares came within striking distance of the buy point early Tuesday, rising as much as 4.2% before trimming gains to 2% in midday trade. Analysts expect the Houston-based company's earnings to grow 566% in 2018.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseOccidental Petroleum (OXY) is pulling back to the 50-day line after a big breakout above a 78.19 cup-shaped base entry. Shares are trading about 7% above the entry.Occidental boasts a 98 out of a highest-possible 99 IBD Composite Rating. The rating is a blend of key fundamental and technical metrics designed to gauge a stock's measure of quality.New York-based Hess (HES) is just below a flat base's 65.99 buy point. Shares broke out on June 27 and the stock's relative strength line hit a new high to confirm the strength of the breakout.Murphy Oil (MUR) is in the 5% buy range from a cup with handle's 32.87 entry. The buy zone tops out at 34.51.Apache (APA) is near a 44.86 buy point in a cup with handle. Shares are just above the buy point.Get instant access to more trading ideas, exclusive stock lists and IBD proprietary ratings for only $5.RELATED:Crude Tops $75, And These 5 Oil Stocks Are Moving Toward Buy PointsEnergy Stocks And Industry News: Oil, Gas, Solar, CoalFed Minutes, ADP Jobs Report, Crude Oil Inventories: Investing Action Plan

Amid President Trump's decision to back out of the Iran nuclear deal and bullish U.S. inventory data, leading energy stocks were boosted by higher oil prices in the stock market today. Oil prices advanced nearly 3% to over $71 a barrel to hit a new high, as EOG Resources (EOG) tried to reclaim a buy point.XOf the top ten performing industry groups Wednesday, four of them were oil and gas related. The Oil & Gas-U.S. Exploration & Production industry group moved up 2.9% in midday trade, easily beating the S&P 500's 1% advance. The industry is ranked No. 9 out of 197 groups, moving up from No. 59 six weeks ago.EOG Resources rose nearly 3% in heavy volume, as the stock continued to recoup more of a five-day string of losses. Shares broke out past a 119.10 cup-shaped base last week, but immediately came under pressure. At its lows, shares fell as much as 6.4% below the buy point. The last two days of strong gains have taken the immediate selling pressure off the stock.Last week, the company said it plans to boost its dividend at a faster pace. In the most recent reported quarter, revenue growth accelerated for a second straight quarter to 41%, vs. the year-ago period.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseOccidental Petroleum (OXY) followed through on a recent breakout above a 78.19 cup base's buy point with a sharp advance Wednesday. Shares reached as high as 83.82, up 7.2%.Late Tuesday, the company reported better-than-expected Q1 results. Occidental also announced it will resume its share buyback program.Its formation is a first-stage base, which is less likely to fail than a later-stage base.Diamondback Energy (FANG) continues to see buying demand Wednesday, as the stock erased an early dive of more than 3% to rally nearly 1% in afternoon trading. Late Tuesday, the company reported strong earnings results, but the stock still fell. Shares are just above a 134.70 buy point in a new narrow cup pattern.Cup bases must be a minimum six weeks in length, or 30 trading sessions on a daily chart.For the quarter, year-over-year revenue saw triple-digit growth for a fifth consecutive quarter.Shares have been volatile and two previous breakouts have failed, resulting in sell signals.First, the stock broke out past a flat base with a 115.03 buy point on Dec. 20. Gains were initially strong, but those gains entirely disappeared in late January, eventually resulting in the down 7%-8% sell signal on Feb. 9.Next, the stock formed a cup with handle with a 131.68 entry. A March 26 breakout quickly faltered, resulting in another 7%-8% loss-cutting sell signal.RELATED:Breakout Watch: No. 1-Ranked Software Stock Salesforce Near Buy ZoneNvidia, These 2 Hot IPOs Lead 5 Top Stocks With Earnings Due: Investing Action PlanEnergy Stocks And Industry News: Oil, Gas, Solar, CoalLooking For Breakout Stocks Like Nvidia? Start With These Lists

Given the steady rise in oil prices since last summer, it's no surprise that energy stocks are dominating the IBD Dividend Leaders list. The leaders are diverse — including oil and gas drillers, refiners, transporters, explorers and producers, and integrated oil and gas giants — like blue chip Chevron (CVX).XAmong the oil and gas integrated stocks, Chevron is holding just above a 128 cup-with-handle buy point Friday. Shares broke out on May 9, but have gained little traction.Chevron's most recent dividend will be paid out on June 11 in the amount of $1.12 per share. The stock has a 3.5% annualized dividend yield.Refiner Occidental Petroleum (OXY) soared to new highs and a breakout last week when it surged over 9% after the company reported strong earnings results on May 8. Shares are about 10% from that buy point. The refiner has a 3.6% annualized yield.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseHelmerich & Payne (HP) is approaching a potential cup-with-handle entry. The buy point is 74.46, according to MarketSmith's chart analysis.The contract drilling company has a solid 3.8% annualized yield and the upcoming dividend is to be paid out on June 1.Enterprise Products Partners (EPD), Magellan Midstream Partners (MMP) and Oneok (OKE) are the three pipeline operators on the Dividend Leaders. Of the three stocks, Enterprise is currently in buy range. Magellan is shaping the right side of a potential cup-shaped base, while Oneok is extended after a recent breakout.Enterprise is about 2% above a 27.55 cup-with-handle entry. The Houston-based natural gas and crude oil pipeline company paid out a nearly 43 cent per share quarterly dividend on May 8. The annualized yield is over 6%.Magellan Midstream is moving up the right side of a base, after recently gaining traction above the long-term 200-day line. The pipeline operator paid out an almost-94 cent per share quarterly dividend on May 15.Lastly, Oneok broke out above a 61.46 flat-base entry on May 2 after the company announced strong earnings results. Shares are extended from the entry. Oneok has a 4.8% annual dividend.RELATED:High-Dividend-Yielding Oil Driller Is Setting Up To move HigherHigher Oil Prices Fortify Energy Stocks like This Pipeline OperatorEnergy Stocks And Industry News: Oil, Gas, Solar, CoalDow Jones Industrial Average And Dow Stocks: News And Analysis

U.S. equity markets closed sharply higher Wednesday as an early rebound in crude oil prices broadened into a solid advance that handed the Dow its fifth straight gain and the Nasdaq a fourth win in a row.More than 75% of the 197 industry groups tracked by IBD moved higher in a session that left the Dow Jones industrial average ahead 0.8%. The S&P 500 grabbed a 1% gain. The Nasdaq Composite also climbed 1%. Exxon Mobil (XOM) was one of five Dow stocks to rise more than 2%. Walmart (WMT) and Walt Disney (DIS) staked out the bottom of the list. Both the Dow and the S&P 500 surfaced for their first real breath of air above their 50-day moving averages since April 18.Crude oil prices easily kept their 42-month highs, while the yield on the 10-year Treasury note remained steady at 3%. Stocks scoring breakouts Wednesday included Chevron (CVX), Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA), Occidental Petroleum (OXY) and Electronic Arts (EA), among others.Energy issues drove the session. Exxon ran near the head of the Dow. Chevron, Shell and Occidental Petroleum scored breakouts. Oil and energy industries made four of the day's seven biggest advances among the 197 industry group tracked by IBD.The price of West Texas intermediate crude settled up 3% at 71.14. That took back more than the ground it lost Tuesday and marked its first close above $71 a barrel since November 2014. Oil prices had turned volatile on Tuesday's news that the U.S. had exited the Iran nuclear deal. A new round of sanctions could take a share of Iranian oil off the international market. Iran, the world's fifth largest oil producer, exported 2.48 million barrels per day in April.Crude oil prices received an added boost Wednesday morning, after the Energy Information Administration reported a 2.2-million-barrel draw on U.S. oil stockpiles last week vs. expectations for a build of 160,000 barrels.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseThe highest flying oil name among S&P 500 stocks, Occidental Petroleum (OXY) snapped more than 5% higher. That effectively marked a breakout above a 78.19 buy point in a cup-without-handle base. Occidental reported a Q1 earnings gain of more than 500%, with revenue rising 28%. Both were well above expectations. The stock rose narrowly above the proper buy point in moderate trade Tuesday.On the Dow, Chevron's heavy volume, 1.6% gain sent shares into a buy range above a 128 buy point in a five-month cup-with-handle base.Royal Dutch Shell gapped up to a 3.3% win, breaking out past a 71.79 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.Airline stocks dived, as investors struggled to price in increased fuel costs. American Airlines Group (AAL) dropped 3.5%. Delta Air Lines (DAL) shed 1.5%. United Continental Holdings (UAL) slumped 3%Walmart was the Dow's stumbling block, ending down 3.3% after announcing it would pay $16 billion to acquire a 77% stake in India's largest e-commerce name, Flipkart. The big box retailer's largest acquisition to date ratchets up Walmart's e-commerce war with Amazon.com (AMZN) in a country where 35% of the country's 1.3 billion citizens use the internet. Wednesday's loss ended Walmart's effort to retake its 50-day moving average, sending the stock to its lowest level since October.Disney shares fell 1.8%, back below their 10-week moving average. The House of Mouse reported a solid fiscal Q2 sales and earnings beat late Tuesday, but ESPN ad revenue, theme-park resort reservations and broadcast subscribers all declined. Disney shares are trading tightly, below the 50-day and 200-day lines, in a five-month consolidation.IBD Leaderboard name Planet Fitness (PLNT) pared a 9% decline to less than 5% at the close. A 42% EPS gain and a 33% jump in Q1 revenue beat analyst expectations. The stock tumbled below its 10-week moving average in heavy trade, which might be a defense-type sell signal following a long run-up in price. The stock fell more than 8% below a 40.14 buy point from a flat base. That triggered the automatic sell rule.Online travel site TripAdvisor (TRIP) spiked 22.8% to top both the Nasdaq 100 and the S&P 500. The company late Wednesday reported a 25% EPS gain in its first quarter, its first earnings advance in nine stanzas. Revenue rose 2%. Both numbers were above analyst estimates. The huge volume move sent shares narrowly above a 47.12 buy point in a bottoming base.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:The Big Picture: Indexes Resilient After Trump DecisionPure Storage, 58.com Are Buys; These 3 Top Stocks Are Setting Up In Same Bullish PatternTrump Scraps Iran Nuclear Deal, But With This CaveatThree Internets, Hot Oil Stock Report Earnings Wednesday; This One Is Near A BuyThese Four Leading Stocks Broke Out Past Buy Points Tuesday

Occidental Petroleum (OXY) continued to rally late Tuesday on strong Q1 earnings and buyback plans, adding to its regular-session breakout, while Diamondback Energy (FANG) pulled back below a buy point late despite strong earnings.XBut oil prices fell after President Trump said the U.S. will pull out of the Iran nuclear deal but delay reimposing sanctions for several month, giving backers time to work out a fix that would save the agreement.Estimates: EPS soaring 373% to 71 cents with revenue climbing 24% to $3.696 billion.Results: EPS of 92 cents on revenue of $3.825 billion. Total production rose 4.6% to 610,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. Permian Resources production, which includes unconventional assets, rose 37% to 177,000 BOE per day on better-than-expected well results, especially in the Greater Sand Dunes region."We are on track to complete our Breakeven Plan in the third quarter and are well positioned for continued strong performance and growth," said CEO Vicki Hollub in a statement. "Therefore, we now intend to resume our long-standing share buyback program."Stock: Occidental rose 2.3% late. Shares rallied 1.2% to finish at 78.20 in heavy volume. On Monday, Occidental cleared a 78.19 entry point from a cup base but closed below it.Occidental has acreage in the Permian Basin shale formation and has operations elsewhere in the U.S. as well as in the Middle East and Latin America. In 2014, Occidental spun off its oil and gas assets in California under the stock California Resources (CRC).Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseEstimates: Earnings jumping 53% to $1.59 per share with revenue up 88.5% to $443 million, according to Zacks Investment Research.Results: EPS of $1.64 on revenue of $480.2 million. Production jumped 67% to 102,600 barrels of oil equivalent per day.Outlook: Management now see full-year production of 110,00-116,000 barrels per day, up 1% from prior guidance at the midpoint, implying 43% annualized growth. The company also maintained its 2018 capital spending outlook at $1.3 billion-$1.5 billion."Diamondback will continue to be active, yet selective, in our acquisition strategy, with accretion and full-cycle economics remaining key drivers of our decision making process," said CEO Travis Stice in a statement.Stock: Diamondback fell 1.6% late. Shares closed up 3.4% to 134.72 on the stock market today, clearing a 130.80 entry point from a cup-with-handle base in heavy volume, after giving up a 131.68 entry of a V-shaped base and hitting the 8% sell rule last month.The shale sector has had a strong earnings season overall, with companies like Matador Resources (MTDR), Continental Resources (CLR) and Pioneer Natural Resources (PXD) beating first-quarter estimates. But investors have also been waiting for companies to return more capital via dividends and buybacks as higher oil prices leave them flush with cash.Last week, EOG Resources (EOG) also beat views and said plans to increase its payout at a faster pace can survive future volatility in oil prices.But with oil prices near the highest levels since late 2014, producers will be more tempted to spend more money on expanding output rather than maintain capital discipline.On Tuesday, the Energy Information Administration raised its estimates on U.S. crude production and now sees 2018 output averaging 10.72 million barrels per day, up 0.3% from a prior forecast, and sees 2019 output averaging 11.86 million barrels a day, a 3.6% upward revision.Editor's note: this story has been updated to clarify Occidental's Permian production.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN: Energy Stocks And Industry News: Oil, Gas, Solar, CoalThe 'Apple Of Oil' Sees Bigger Dividend Lasting Through Oil Swings

Chevron (CVX) cleared a buy point intraday while fellow oil major Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA) neared a breakout buoyed by the rise in West Texas Intermediate crude prices moving above $70 as President Donald Trump mulls whether to exit the Iran nuclear deal.The price of West Texas intermediate rose 1.5% to settle at $70.73 per barrel, the first time prices were that high since late 2014, when a global oil glut sent prices reeling. Brent crude was around $76.But shortly after crude futures settled, Trump tweeted that he will announce his decision on the Iran nuclear deal at 2 p.m. ET on Tuesday. U.S. crude futures fell to about $69.80 in electronic trading. Investors may be taking some profits in case Trump decides not to pull out of the deal.Chevron fell 0.5% to 124.94 in the stock market today after briefly clearing a 128 entry of a handle in a cup base. Royal Dutch Shell, reversing modestly lower to down 0.2% at 69.72, has been trying to break out of a handle formation with a 71.79 buy point.Elsewhere, Occidental Petroleum (OXY) broke out of a cup base intraday with a 78.19 buy point. But the move was in low volume and the stock reversed to down 0.6% at 77.27. Occidental reports on Tuesday.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseOasis Petroleum (OAS) jumped as high as 11.88, breaking out of a long cup base with a 11.49 buy point, but also in low volume. Oasis pared gains to up 1.1% at 11.34, below the entry. Oasis reports late Monday.Carrizo Oil & Gas (CRZO), which also reports late today, advanced 1%.President Trump could reimpose sanctions on Iran, a move that could constrain the world's oil supply. Under the Iran nuclear deal, struck in 2015, Tehran agreed to scale back its nuclear program in exchange for the sanction relief."While President Trump has not publicly announced his decision on the May 12 Iran sanctions waivers, it seems that the bureaucratic wheels are turning in Washington to prepare for a sanctions snapback and a renewed effort to reduce Iranian exports," RBC analysts said in a research note dated Monday."While there is a scenario where Trump opts to waive sanctions once again due to North Korea, we think it is more likely that he opts to exit this week," the note continued.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:Energy Stocks And Industry News: Oil, Gas, Solar, Coal6 Oil Stocks Offer Buy Points As Earnings Come DueExxon Puts This Ahead Of Dividends, Buybacks As Earnings Miss AgainWarren Buffett-Backed Oil Refiner Phillips 66 Earnings Top Views

Oil prices spiked Monday after Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu claimed that he has documents that show Iran cheated on the nuclear deal that allowed it to boost crude exports.XNetanyahu said he has a cache of tens of thousands of documents from a "highly secret location" in Iran that showed Tehran was working on nuclear weapons to get around investigators.He added that he met with new Secretary of State Mike Pompeo over the weekend and said he shared the cache with the U.S., and that the U.S. could "vouch for its authenticity."U.S. oil prices climbed 0.7% to $68.47 a barrel, paring gains after jumping 1.7% earlier. Brent oil prices rose 0.7% to $75.17 per barrel. Crude had earlier gotten a boost, after Israel was suspected of launching airstrikes in on Iran-linked targets in Syria over the weekend.EOG Resources (EOG), which reports earnings Thursday, was up 1.2% at 118.17 on the stock market today, nearing its 119.10 buy point in a first-stage cup base. Matador Resources (MTDR), which reports Wednesday, rallied 0.9% to 32.74, closing in on a 34.06 entry. BP (BP) rose 0.8% to 44.59, almost retaking a 44.72 buy point from a cup base initially cleared last week. Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA) added 0.2% to 69.91, working on a 71.72 buy point in a cup-with-handle base. Occidental Petroleum (OXY) rose 0.3% to 77.26, nearing a 78.19 entry.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UsePresident Trump has until May 12 to decide if he will reinstate the sanctions that were lifted as part of the Iran nuclear deal.  Trump, along with Israel and Saudi Arabia, has been vocal critic of the multilateral agreement.But China, France, Germany, Russia and the U.K. have supported the deal, and the International Energy Agency has said Tehran has been complying to the deal. The leaders of France and Germany also personally urged Trump to stick with the deal in separate White House visits last week.Pompeo has also increased the likelihood of harsher sanctions against Iran, James Williams, an economist at energy consultant WTRG told IBD last month.Williams said sanctions with Iran would reduce Iranian oil production, noting that oil prices hit $100 a barrel when the Obama administration levied sanctions on Iran. While oil won't hit $100 this time, he said prices will still go higher.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN: Energy Stocks And Industry News: Oil, Gas, Solar, CoalEarnings Calendar, Analyst Estimates And Stocks To WatchStocks Near Buy Zone Ahead Of Earnings

BP (BP) cleared a buy point Tuesday, attempting to join ConocoPhillips (COP) and several other recent energy breakouts. U.S. crude oil futures briefly topped $69 a barrel Tuesday, the highest since late 2014, as Saudi Arabia-led OPEC looks to continue production cuts with Russia and push prices even higher.U.S. crude as high as $69.38 a barrel but reversed to close down 1.4% to $67.70 as the S&P 500 index and Dow Jones industrial average turned lower. Brent crude fell 1.1% to $73.86 after eclipsing $75 intraday.Global supplies have been falling due to the ongoing production cuts. U.S. crude stockpiles likely fell for a second straight week. The American Petroleum Institute will release its weekly estimates of crude and gasoline supplies late Tuesday, with the Energy Information Administration reporting official inventory and production data Wednesday morning.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseEnergy groups are leading the market with many oil stocks' relative strength lines hitting new highs even before the share price. A few more energy stocks attempted breakouts intraday, though the reversal in crude futures and the S&P 500 provided some resistance.BP rose as high as 44.81, just peeking out past a 44.72 entry point from a cup base. BP closed up 0.8% at 44.25.Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA) closed flat at 71.10, but working toward a 72.53 buy point in a cup base.Occidental Petroleum (OXY) edged up 0.1% to 77.33, working on a cup base with a 78.19 entry.Shale leader EOG Resources (EOG) shares dipped 0.2% to 114.59, building the right side of a cup base with a 119.10 buy point.Fellow shale player Matador Resources (MTDR) fell 1.2% to 33.31, after rising intraday to 34.23, briefly topping a 34.06 entry.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN: Oil Prices Hit Fresh High As OPEC, Russia Avoid 'Mission Accomplished' Victory LapJagged Peak Energy Sketches 3 Interesting PatternsEnergy Stocks And Industry News: Oil, Gas, Solar, CoalStocks Near A Buy ZoneCrude Oil Prices Are Up Sharply, But Is The Bakken Shale Play Back?

It seems that everything is going the energy sector's way.The price of oil is trending higher, and the sector is expected to blow the doors off second-quarter earnings. Energy companies on the whole are expected to expand earnings 139.8% in Q2 as the sector continues to emerge from a two-year earnings recession, according to research firm CFRA.Indeed, many companies' earnings are still coming up against easy year-ago comparisons. For example, the consensus estimate for Occidental Petroleum's (OXY) EPS of 693% growth compares against a profit of just 15 cents a share in Q2 of 2017.Crude is the tide that lifts all oil stocks, and the price of U.S. oil briefly topped $75 a barrel the past week. It was the highest level since November 2014. Major oil-producing countries are keeping supplies from swelling, and supply constraints pop up in Iran, Libya and Venezuela. Meanwhile, producers continue driving down costs.Among IBD's industry groups, only U.S. exploration and production is in the top 20 of 197 groups. Drilling is No. 57.Energy's expected profit growth is far above any other sector. The second-best sector is materials, with a projected growth of 29.6% thanks to higher commodity prices and higher volumes, says Lindsey Bell, CFRA investment strategist.Financials and information technology are forecast to grow profits 22.7% and 21.3%, respectively. The other seven S&P sectors are estimated to lag the S&P 500's overall profit increase.Technology remains the market's big profit engine. It's headed for the seventh quarter in a row in the top three sectors and the eighth quarter with double-digit growth, Bell notes. Telecommunications is seen rising 15.2%, industrials 14.1%, consumer discretionary 13.4%, health care 9.9% and consumer staples 7.4%. Real estate and utilities are the only sector indicated to decrease Q2 earnings, down 3.8% and 1.5%.For the entire S&P 500, CFRA sees another strong quarter of 19.5% growth. Historically, quarterly growth ends up 3.5 to 4.5 percentage points higher than initial estimates. That might put final earnings up 23%, on par with the 23.3% increase recorded in the first quarter."We expect this will be the second quarter in a row for earnings growth of greater than 20%, something that hasn't been recorded since 2010 (a result of a rebound in earnings off recessionary declines)," Bell wrote in a June 28 report. "This time the robust growth rate is a reflection of strong sales growth and reduced tax rates from the new tax policy."Revenue for the S&P 500 is expected to increase 8.9%. Materials is forecast to grow sales 30.3%, energy 19.7%, health care 14.7% and technology 11.4%. Consumer staples and utilities are the only sectors expected to report a decline in sales.Get instant access to more trading ideas, exclusive stock lists and IBD proprietary ratings for only $5.RELATED:Permian Oil Prices Dive As Gas Prices Rise, Boosting These RefinersTop Shale Oil Names See Profits Soar As Crude Passes $70

When Occidental Petroleum (OXY) packed up its Los Angeles, Calif., headquarters and shipped out to Houston in 2014, few investors had heard of the Permian Basin. At the time, Occidental was the largest oil producer in Texas. It was the largest producer of natural gas in California.By 2017, the almost century-old company was the third-largest oil play in Texas. That put it just behind EOG Resources (EOG) and Pioneer Natural Resources (PXD). It is also among the largest holders of acreage and producers of oil in the Permian Basin. That is the west Texas redoubt that Bloomberg has said is on track to "become the world's largest oil patch over the next decade."Occidental shares slipped 2.4% in weak trade Monday, edging just below the stock's 50-day moving average. The move technically put the stock back into a buy range above a 78.18 buy point in a cup base. Investors probably don't want to enter a stock that high in the buy range. But a rebound off the 50-day line could produce a follow-on buying opportunity.Many Permian producers face a musical chairs-type shake out, as production outpaces the available capacity of pipelines to transport the oil to market. But Occidental owns its own gathering systems within the basin, the pipelines that take oil and gas from the wellhead to larger pipelines or to separation facilities.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseAlso, Occidental has locked down contracts giving them capacity of 470,000 barrels per day out of the Permian, according to a CNBC interview with chief executive Vicki Hollub in May. At that time, that was roughly double the company's output within the basin, she said.In mid-June, capacity bottlenecks trimmed prices for oil coming out of the Permian to about $10 below West Texas Intermediate crude priced at Cushing, Okla., the transaction location for the WTI benchmark. The International Energy Agency believes take-away capacity from the Permian fields will "become insufficient by midyear, with a deficit possibly reaching as much as 290,000 barrels a day during the first half of 2019."In addition, Occidental is expanding the loading capacity of its Ingleside oil export terminal in Corpus Christi, Texas. It is adding loading arms and dredging the terminal to a depth of 66 feet, allowing it to load VLCC tankers — the largest class of oil tanker afloat — with oil headed for markets in Europe and Asia. Crude exports out of Corpus Christi are expected to reach 1 million barrels per day by 2020.In 2013, just before its move to Texas, Occidental began exiting locations in the Bakken shale of Montana and North Dakota. It spun off its operations in California, and divested four international operations. As a result, production decreased 40% — just as the global oil glut was swinging into gear. Earnings per share dropped by 98%, to 12 cents, in 2015, followed by a $1-per-share loss the following year.Earnings recovered to 89 cents per share last year. They are projected to rebound to $4.61 for 2018, with a 673% jump projected by the consensus estimate for the second quarter.Occidental operates in three segments: oil and gas, chemicals and midstream and marketing. In 2017, the oil and gas unit produced about 63% of revenue. Chemicals were another 35%. The oil unit generated 55% of total earnings. Chemicals were 41%.The strength of diversification was apparent in the segment numbers. For 2017, Occidental's operations outside the U.S. accounted for more than 100% of profit, because domestic operations and oil exploration efforts both lost money.An increasing number of analysts are questioning how much longer the Permian basin can continue to increase its total output, and at what point the Permian's localized glut might began to spread.Hollub said she expects additional pipeline capacity will be built, easing the take-away restrictions. More crucial, she told CNBC, are labor shortages plaguing the industry.She said companies attempting to ramp activity much above current levels are in for a struggle, and face rising costs."We're really at the activity level we want to be," she said, pointing to Occidental's current output from the field. "If you are a company that is not trying to ramp up significantly, you have a significant advantage."Occidental has delivered uninterrupted quarterly dividends since 1975, with annual increases each year since 2002. The current annual rate is $3.08 per share, which yields about 3.7% on an annualized basis.RELATED: Dow Giant Triggers Sell Signal As China Trade War Boosts RivalIBD Stock Of The Day: This China Internet Gives Back All Its GainsPermian Oil Prices Dive As Gas Prices Rise, Boosting These RefinersTop Shale Oil Names See Profits Soar As Crude Passes $70Divergence In The Stock Market Is A Worrisome Sign

Diamondback Energy (FANG) and Occidental Petroleum (OXY) reported fourth-quarter results above Wall Street estimates Tuesday as the International Energy Agency predicted that U.S. production will rise faster this year than global demand growth.X Diamondback reported adjusted earnings of $1.56 per share with revenue of $399.2 million. Analysts expected EPS of $1.52 with revenue of $371 million.The U.S. shale producer sees full-year production of 108,000 to 116,000 barrels per day, up 40% from 2017's output midpoint. It issued full-year capital-spending guidance of $1.3 million to $1.5 million.Diamondback shares rose 5.4% in late trade on the stock market today. Diamondback led several breakouts from the oil patch in late December, but with oil prices pulling back and the stock market falling into a correction, Diamondback and other oil stocks have been big losers this month.Occidental's core diluted EPS was 41 cents vs. a loss of 13 cents in the year-ago quarter. Revenue was $3.59 billion. Analysts expected EPS of 39 cents on revenue of $3.5 billion.The company set its 2018 capital-spending budget at $3.9 billion and sees 8%-12% production growth for the year.Shares were not yet active after hours.IBD'S TAKE: Read IBD's The Big Picture column each day to stay on top of the market direction, a key indicator that lets you know when you can be aggressive and when you should move to the sidelines.In its monthly report Tuesday, the IEA raised its global oil-demand growth outlook to 1.4 million barrels per day, up from 1.3 million bpd in the month-ago report. Oil demand grew at a rate of 1.6 million bpd last year.But U.S. crude output will likely outpace demand growth as the IEA expects U.S. production to overtake Saudi Arabia "soon" and "catch up to Russia by the end of the year.""Today, having cut costs dramatically, U.S. producers are enjoying a second wave of growth so extraordinary that in 2018 their increase in liquids production could equal global demand growth," the Paris-based energy watchdog said in the report.Earlier the U.S. Energy Information Administration said domestic production could hit 11 million bpd by the end of 2018.The IEA report was similar to OPEC's monthly report out Monday. The cartel said it sees global demand growth increasing by 60,000 barrels per day to 1.59 million, putting total global consumption this year at 98.6 million bpd.But the demand increase comes as it raised U.S. production growth by 150,000 bpd.The IEA said demand for OPEC oil this year will average 32.3 million bpd. Compliance with the production-cut deal to remove 1.8 million bpd from the market hit 137% last month on a drop in production from Venezuela, as an economic crisis hit production.U.S. crude fell 10 cents to $59.19 per barrel.Exxon Mobil (XOM) dipped 0.2%. Chevron (CVX) slid 0.6%. Exxon and Chevron are Dow Jones components that both reported weak Q4 earnings on Feb. 2.BP (BP) fell 0.45%. Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA) rose 0.3%.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN: Why The Stock Market Sold Off, And What You Should Do NowEnergy Stocks And Industry News: Oil, Gas, Solar, Coal

Diamondback Energy (FANG) is near a deal to buy Silver Hill Energy Partners, the Wall Street Journal reported late Friday, which would the latest in a series of Permian Basin investments.Diamondback Energy could announce deal for the private-equity owned Silver Hill next week, the WSJ reported, though it's possible the deal will fall apart or that a new bidder will emerge.Noble Energy (NBL), Marathon Oil (MRO) and Occidental Petroleum (OXY) had been seen as mulling offers for Permian-heavy Silver Hill, which owns key assets in the basin. Pioneer Natural Resources (PXD) said last week that 100 rigs could be added to the highly productive Permian.Earlier this month, EOG Resources (EOG) announced it would purchase privately held Yates Petroleum to expand its presence in the Permian. And in July, Diamondback Energy bought $560 million worth of assets in the southern portion of the Permian. The Permian is in West Texas and SE New Mexico.U.S. oil rigs rose by seven to 425 this week, Baker Hughes reported Friday, the highest in seven months. Rigs in the Permian Basin rose by three to 204, nearly half.IBD'S TAKE: Soaring oil prices triggered a slew of shale players breaking out of consolidations and rebounding from 10-week lines, including Diamondback.Oil prices shot up 8.5% for the week after OPEC agreed to cut production, essentially ending its two-year effort to drive out U.S. shale players. Shale stocks surged for the week.Diamondback Energy rose 1.1% on the stock market today and 8.6% for the week. There was little action in late trading, as the Silver Hill report came out well past the closing bell. On Friday, Noble Energy rose 0.5%, Marathon Oil fell 0.6% and Occidental added 1.1%.RELATED:Oil Hits 1-Month High As OPEC Blinks Vs. U.S. Shale; Deal FraysOil Price Rise Puts These U.S. Stocks In Position To Profit

Apache (APA) shares jumped early Wednesday on a report that Occidental Petroleum (OXY) offered to buy the firm, but Occidental said it has no knowledge of a bid.A report from Oil and Gas People said Oxy would announce a deal worth at least $25 billion for Apache. But Oxy told Reuters "We don't have any knowledge around this topic."Apache shares closed up 2.7% in the stock market today. Occidental shares lost 2%.In November, Anadarko Petroleum (APC) withdrew its offer to buy Apache, which rejected the deal without discussing the matter with Anadarko.Meanwhile, oil prices have been rallying in recent weeks on signs the global supply glut may be easing as well as on production disruptions in Canada and Nigeria.But crude futures pared gains Wednesday after the Energy Information Administration reported a surprise domestic inventory increase of 1.3 million barrels vs. forecasts for a decline of 3 million barrels and the American Petroleum Institute's report late Tuesday for a drawdown of 1.14 million barrels.Brent crude fell 0.7% to end at $48.93 a barrel. U.S. crude dipped 0.3% to settle at $48.19 a barrel.

Despite a decline in U.S. output, oil stockpiles keep rising -- thanks to unabated production overseas -- but a "serious" supply drop will be seen soon, potentially helping shares of Exxon Mobil (XOM), Chevron (CVX), BP (BP) and Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA).The continued buildup in inventory has weighed on crude prices, creating stumbling blocks to a recent rally. On Friday, U.S. crude futures rose 0.9% to $47.75 a barrel, but are still near 2016 highs and gained 3% for the week.Exxon shares closed down 0.4% in the stock market today. Chevron fell less than 0.1%, BP dipped 0.15%, and Royal Dutch Shell ended virtually flat. Baker Hughes (BHI) said U.S. oil rigs in operation were unchanged this week at 318, the first time in nine weeks that it hasn't fallen.Since hitting a high of 9.61 million barrels a day in June 2015, U.S. production has fallen 8.5%. But in that time, inventory excluding the Strategic Petroleum Reserve has climbed 15%. Since June 2014, the stockpile has jumped 40%, raising fears that U.S. storage capacity will hit its limit and send any new supply to flood the spot market.On Wednesday, the Energy Information Administration reported a surprise inventory increase of 1.3 million barrels vs. forecasts for a decline of 3 million barrels. But production fell to 8.79 million barrels per day from 8.8 million barrels a week earlier.Helped by lower costs and efficiency improvements, U.S. output has been surprisingly resilient, with producers like Occidental Petroleum (OXY), Apache (APA) and Continental Resources (CLR) also recently raising their 2016 output forecasts.Factors outside the U.S. are also at play. Canadian oil that was in the pipelines before wildfires hit in the oil sands region of the Alberta province are just now making it to the U.S. Further, imports from the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries remain strong, according to Phil Flynn, senior market analyst at the Price Futures Group."I think OPEC has been sending every barrel they can, but I think that now it will start to fall as output in OPEC nations slow, Iraq output has peaked, and Venezuela is a shambles," Flynn wrote in an email."Nigeria also is falling, and even Saudi Arabia production is falling. The wildfires' impact will be felt in the weeks to come because we are still seeing (that) old production just hit our storage. That will soon fall to a trickle."Flynn expects to see "serious oil supply drops in the coming weeks."Militants have blocked workers from getting to Exxon Mobil's terminal in Nigeria. On Thursday, an official from Lukoil told Bloomberg that Iraq's production has likely peaked and will fall under targets over the next two years.

More than $1 billion a day. That's the price tag for a Permian Basin pipeline crunch that's increasingly affecting investors as much as it is West Texas oil drillers.Eight of the top explorers focused on the booming U.S. shale region have lost $15.6 billion in combined market value in about two weeks, as shipping constraints devour the profit they can fetch for a barrel of crude. Parsley Energy (PE) shares have wilted 16% in that time; Diamondback Energy (FANG) has been defanged, down 18%.Even as production soars, dwindling pipeline space and a rail and trucking shortage have raised shipping costs, boosting the discount Permian producers take to offload their oil. The bottleneck benefits refiners who can buy cheaper crude and pipeline owners with extra space, but it's dragging down explorers."You just don't want to touch these Permian names," said Gabriele Sorbara, a Williams Capital Group analyst in New York. "They are falling off a cliff."Relief may not come until 2020, when new pipelines are expected to be up and running. For now, here's a rundown of winners and losers amid the space crunch:Being a "pure play" shale producer, even a Permian stalwart, is no longer the ticket to success for energy equities.Since May 21, the price of benchmark West Texas intermediate crude has fallen about 10% and companies focused primarily on the Permian have been shunned. The hardest fall: Concho Resources (CXO), which has lost $4.1 billion off its market capitalization as of Tuesday.As of Wednesday, oil in Midland, Texas, was trading for about $19 a barrel below Brent crude, the global benchmark price.Even Pioneer Natural Resources (PXD), with relatively strong finances and secure pipeline contracts, has been swept up, Williams Capital's Sorbara said by phone. It's lost $3.2 billion in market value, or 9%, since May 21.While the shortages are real, he deems much of the market sell-off "overblown," since even discounted Permian crude is selling for well above where many producers set their budgets earlier this year.Investors, though, are fleeing to the relative safety of larger names with more diverse portfolios such as Occidental Petroleum (OXY), whose shares are flat over the past couple weeks. The Permian's biggest oil producer also pumps in the Middle East and Colombia, with roughly 40% of its output this year based on higher international crude pricing, Capital One Securities said in an analyst note.The company also operates pipelines and a Gulf Coast export terminal that will benefit from cheaper U.S. crude prices. "The largest companies or companies with diverse portfolios can rotate capital around," Sorbara said. "If you're a pure play, the only thing you can do is step on the brakes."With bottlenecks between the Permian and major Gulf Coast refiners, operators in other parts of the country served by less-congested pipelines have a relative advantage, analysts say.That includes Delek US (DK), CVR Refining (CVRR) and HollyFrontier (HFC), with refineries in New Mexico, Arkansas and northeastern Texas, among other locations, according to Barclays. Delek gets about 78% of its crude from the Permian, HollyFrontier gets 39% and CVR gets 14%, the bank said in a June 5 analyst report.Delek shares have climbed 7.5% in the past two weeks while CVR is up 3.3% and HollyFrontier is up 1%."Simply put, we think U.S. refiners win big with lower input costs," analysts including Justin Jenkins at Raymond James & Associates said in a June 4 note.Enterprise Products Partners and Magellan Midstream Partners also stand to benefit from the blowout in Midland prices as they own crucial pipelines in the Permian and dock space on the Gulf used for exports — and have plans to add more."The very idea of congestion is beneficial," said Sandy Fielden, director of oil research at Chicago-based Morningstar. "If I'm going to pitch my new pipeline or expand my pipeline, and I'm going to hold my open season, I can expect to see a full crowd there anxious to sign up quickly."Enterprise started full service in April on its 416-mile Midland-to-Sealy pipeline, which can carry some 575,000 barrels per day of crude from the heart of the Permian to key export facilities in Houston. They also own the lion's share of crude storage tanks and docks along the Gulf.Magellan operates and owns part of the 400,000-barrel-a-day BridgeTex pipeline, transporting oil from the Permian to Corpus Christi, Texas. That route is scheduled for expansion in early 2019 because of added interest. The company said last month that almost all existing customers on its Longhorn pipeline, connecting the Permian to Houston, have renewed their contracts for two years.

The Dow Jones and S&P 500 reclaimed their 50-day moving average. Crude oil rose above $71 a barrel and energy stocks such as Chevron (CVX) kept rising after President Trump pulled out from the Iran nuclear deal. Walmart (WMT) will buy 77% of Flipkart with a $16 billion investment. Nvidia (NVDA) crushed earnings views. Several top software makers broke out on earnings. China internets had mixed results, while solar stocks shined on earnings and new regulation.XThe S&P 500, Dow Jones industrial average and Nasdaq composite rallied strongly, rising 2.4%, 2.3% and 2.7%, respectively. The S&P 500 and Dow joined the Nasdaq above their 50-day moving averages. Breakouts proliferated, including several oil, payments and software stocks.President Trump announced the U.S. would leave the nuclear deal and the global oil markets could lose 500,000 barrels per day of Iranian crude next year if all the sanctions are reinstituted. Crude, which had rallied strongly leading up to the announcement, topped $71 a barrel after the decision. Crude closed the week up 1.4% at $70.70. The Energy Information Administration now sees 2018 U.S. crude output averaging 10.72 million barrels per day, up 0.3% from a prior forecast, and sees 2019 output averaging 11.86 million barrels a day, a 3.6% upward revision. The EIA said weekly crude inventories fell by 2.2 million barrels last week, more than analysts forecast. Domestic crude output climbed to 10.7 million barrels per day. Occidental Petroleum (OXY) announced strong Q1 earnings and buyback plans. Diamondback Energy (FANG) Q1 results also beat analyst estimates. Oil majors Chevron (CVX) and Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA) cleared buy points.Green Dot (GDOT), which provides prepaid cards and other financial products, soared past a buy point on strong earnings. Payments tech company Worldpay (WP) beat Q1 estimates, but its outlook appeared to disappoint Wall Street, pushing shares away from buying territory. Visa (V), and Square (SQ) remained within buy range, moving to the high end of the range. Mastercard (MA) is slightly extending. Payments processor Global Payments (GPN) made its way through a base.Graphics-chip maker Nvidia smashed Wall Street's targets for its fiscal first quarter thanks to strong gaming and data-center chip sales. Nvidia earned $1.98 a share, up 151% year over year, on sales of $3.21 billion, up 66%. For the current quarter, its Q2, Nvidia expects sales to rise 39% to $3.1 billion, edging views of $2.97 billion. But it sees a big drop in cryptocurrency chip sales. Shares fell 2.15% Friday after rallying to a new high ahead of its earnings. Microchip Technology (MCHP) beat consensus for the March quarter and guided current-quarter views slightly higher.SolarEdge (SEDG) surged as the solar power company reported strong first-quarter earnings and gave bullish guidance. SolarEdge will enter the multibillion dollar market for uninterruptible power supply systems, by agreeing to buy Gamatronic Electronic. Solar stocks rallied across the board, including SunPower (SPWR) and Sunrun (RUN), after California became the first state to require solar panels on almost all new homes.Walmart (WMT) has beaten Amazon (AMZN) in their battle for control of Flipkart by agreeing to pay $16 billion for a 77% stake in the Indian e-commerce giant, which was founded by ex-Amazon employees. Walmart says it's a "significant opportunity" to partner with the local leader in a large, fast-growing market. But Walmart's slumping stock fell to a seven-month low. Walmart's largest-ever acquisition requires regulatory approval in India.Social network Weibo (WB) and parent Sina (SINA) topped first-quarter earnings estimates, but both stocks suffered double-digit losses. E-commerce company JD.com (JD) received price target cuts following a quarterly report that fell short of Wall Street estimates, though revenue beat. China auto website provider Autohome (ATHM) reported better-than-expected earnings and also nudged second-quarter revenue forecasts higher, sending the stock up.Online travel company Booking Holdings (BKNG), formerly Priceline, plunged as it reported quarterly results that beat views but gave an outlook that missed estimates, as the company makes ongoing changes to its marketing strategy. TripAdvisor (TRIP) soared after delivering a first-quarter report above consensus and raising 2018 guidance on stronger mobile monetization.New Relic (NEWR), Pegasystems (PEGA), Cornerstone OnDemand (CSOD) all broke out on earnings reports, with Upland Software (UPLD) and HubSpot (HUBS) flirting with a buy zone. RingCentral (RNG) moved above a buy range on results.New Relic, whose cloud software lets companies monitor business applications, servers and mobile applications, swung to a 9-cent profit, vs. views for 5 cents, with revenue up 34% to $98.4 million and billings up 43%. Pegasystems earnings fell more than expected, but the customer service software maker's revenue topped. Cornerstone OnDemand earnings grew 75% with revenue up 19% to $133 million. Upland, which makes software for project and information technology management, workflow automation, and digital engagement, reported that adjusted profit leapt 131% and revenue 52%. HubSpot profit spiked 400% while 2018 EPS guidance was strong. RingCentral said that adjusted earnings were 16 cents a share, up 77% from a year ago, with revenue rising 34% to $150 million. Its cloud communications platform offers customers voice, chat, conferencing and app integration.LGI Homes (LGIH) EPS jumped 115% as revenue popped 71% to $279 million, both much better than views. But shares reversed sharply lower as the entry-level homebuilders said costs were rising. Meanwhile, simulated-wood decking products maker Trex (TREX) and building materials firm TopBuild (BLD) broke out on strong earnings. Real estate website operator Zillow (Z) rose for the week after initially tumbling following its earnings beat.Comcast (CMCSA) has reportedly thrown its hat into the ring in a bid for 21st Century Fox (FOXA) entertainment assets with a $60 billion bid, trying to trump a Walt Disney (DIS) deal. Disney's studio revenue popped 21% in Q2, as overall revenue at the media giant rose 7% to $14.23 billion and EPS grew 12% to $1.68, topping views. "Black Panther" was a highlight. The theme parks unit grew 13%. Disney said its ESPN+ streaming service is off to a good start. Meanwhile, 21st Century Fox EPS fell 9% to 49 cents a share, missing estimates, on a 2% revenue slip to $7.42 billion, above views.Dropbox (DBX) earned an adjusted 8 cents a share, up from 2 cents a year ago, doubling estimates of 4 cents in its first quarterly report since its March IPO. Revenue rose 28% to $316 million, beating estimates of $267 million. The provider of data-storage and business-collaboration services forecast June quarter and 2018 revenue slightly above estimates.Takeda Pharmaceuticals put up a winning $62 billion bid to buy rare-disease specialist Shire (SHPG) in a deal expected to close in the first half of 2019.Ligand Pharmaceuticals (LGND) reported adjusted income of $1.55 per share on $56.2 million in sales, rising a respective 172% and 92% year over year to top views.Etsy (ETSY) reported first-quarter results that topped views and showed improving fundamentals, with the e-commerce site's growth accelerating and margin expanding as it raised 2018 guidance.Planet Fitness (PLNT) topped first-quarter estimates, but costs rose and the fitness chain didn't raise guidance. Shares fell nearly 5% Wednesday but were up 0.1% for the week.SailPoint (SAIL) reported adjusted Q1 earnings and revenue that beat expectations but in-line guidance for the June quarter disappointed, sending shares in the cybersecurity firm down. SailPoint sells identity management software that helps companies monitor security breaches.GoDaddy (GDDY) reported Q1 profit that met views as revenue and free cash flow beat, sending shares up. Analysts expect the web hosting and internet domain registering company to use growing FCF for acquisitions and to expand internationally.Trade Desk (TTD) earned 34 cents a share, up 88%, on revenue of $85.7 million, up 61%, blasting past views for 10 cents and $73.2 million. The online ad tech firm forecast Q2 revenue of $103 million vs. estimates of $95 million. Shares vaulted 43% on Friday.Video game publisher Electronic Arts (EA) reported better-than-expected results for its fiscal fourth quarter thanks to strength in key franchises such as "FIFA," "Battlefield" and "The Sims."Streaming video platform Roku (ROKU) delivered a beat-and-raise first-quarter report on gains in advertising-supported internet video channels. Roku ended the quarter with 20.8 million active accounts, up 1.5 million from the end of 2017, but shares fell.Zebra Technologies (ZBRA), a maker of asset tracking systems, trounced expectations for first-quarter sales and earnings and guided analysts up for the current quarter, sending its stock soaring.Starbucks (SBUX) will get $7.15 billion up-front from Nestle, which will sell Starbucks products around the world. Starbucks will use the cash to accelerate share buybacks and return $20 billion in cash to shareholders via buybacks and dividends.

What sticks out when you review the latest list of new buys by the best mutual funds? Potential breakout stocks. UnitedHealth (UNH), Best Buy (BBY), Charles Schwab (SCHW) and others are stocks to watch as they may be setting up for new breakout moves when a stronger market rally returns.During a market pullback like we've seen recently, leading stocks will often consolidate prior gains and form new chart patterns, such as a flat base or cup with handle.Other stocks, like alcohol distributor Constellation Brands (STZ) or Famous Footwear owner Calares (CAL), will try to break out but hit resistance.Bottom line: The time to build your list of stocks to watch is when the market is under selling pressure or in a correction.
